diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often accompanies other immune system disorders such as rheumatoid arthritis and lupus. Xerosis (dry skin) and difficulty finding words can be associated with this condition.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Eustachian Tube Dysfunction
diagnoses.description: Can lead to repeated cases of otitis externa, along with other complications. It’s a condition in which the Eustachian tube, which connects the middle ear to the throat, fails to open properly.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of the body, including the joints, skin (xerosis), and nervous system (potential word-finding difficulty), along with kidney problems that can lead to pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that can lead to various symptoms beyond joint inflammation, including skin dryness (xerosis) and, in severe cases, lung involvement (pneumonia).

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Underactive thyroid can cause a variety of symptoms including dry skin (xerosis) and cognitive issues such as word-finding difficulties. Also, due to lowered immunity, patients may be more susceptible to infections like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: Though primarily affecting the ovaries and reproductive system, PCOS can have widespread systemic effects that could indirectly exacerbate conditions like endometriosis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV erodes the body's immune system, making it more susceptible to infections such as pneumonia. It can also indirectly affect cognitive functions, potentially leading to word-finding difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Chronic diabetes can lead to a condition called diabetic dermopathy, which can present as xerosis. Diabetes also affects other bodily systems and can increase the risk of infections such as pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Depression or Anxiety
diagnoses.description: Mood disorders can manifest physically with psychosomatic symptoms like word-finding difficulty due to decreased concentration, or indirectly influence the severity of other symptoms through neglect of self-care.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress or Fatigue
diagnoses.description: Prolonged stress or fatigue can exacerbate symptoms like xerosis, increase susceptibility to infections like otitis externa and pneumonia, and present cognitive symptoms such as word-finding difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken the blood, slowing its flow, and can cause complications such as easy bleeding and clotting. Polycythemia vera can also lead to leukoplakia due to increased blood flow and cell turnover in the oral mucosa.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body produces too many platelets, leading to easy bleeding and clotting. Symptoms may include episodic weakness and occasional problems with concentration or attention due to blood flow issues.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause high numbers of white blood cells and platelets, leading to symptoms like easy bleeding, weakness, and sometimes leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, causing scar tissue to form in the bone marrow. Symptoms can include easy bleeding, weakness, and polycythemia in the early stages.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a lack of healthy red blood cells due to insufficient iron, leading to episodic weakness and easy bleeding. Although not directly related to polycythemia, its symptom of weakness can be confused with more serious conditions.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by clotting in small blood vessels (thromboses), leading to a low platelet count (thrombocytopenia), episodic weakness, and sometimes neurological symptoms affecting attention.

diagnoses.name: Hemophilia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the blood doesn't clot normally because of a lack of sufficient blood-clotting proteins. Individuals may experience easy bleeding even with minor injuries.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency of von Willebrand factor, which helps blood cells stick together when they need to clot. This can lead to easy bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells which can cause a high level of calcium in the blood, leading to frequent urination, weakness, and confusion. It can be associated with bleeding gums or nosebleeds due to the effects on blood cell production.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though primarily affecting metabolism, severe or untreated hypothyroidism can lead to reduced production of clotting factors, contributing to easy bleeding, and can indirectly affect attention through overall slowing of cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest.

diagnoses.name: Kounis Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A type of acute coronary syndrome that results from an allergic or hypersensitivity reaction.

diagnoses.name: Vulvodynia
diagnoses.description: Chronic pain or discomfort around the opening of the vagina, for which there's no identifiable cause and which lasts at least 3 months.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcers
diagnoses.description: Sores that develop on the lining of your stomach, lower esophagus, or small intestine, typically resulting from inflammation caused by H. pylori bacteria or from erosion due to stomach acids.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by feelings of anxiety and fear.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: An intestinal disorder causing pain in the belly, gas, diarrhea, and constipation.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the body's immune system attacks healthy cells by mistake.

diagnoses: Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anemia

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to a variety of symptoms, including hypothermia and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: A life-threatening condition caused by the body's response to an infection, which can lead to tissue damage, organ failure, and death. Symptoms can include hypothermia, tachycardia, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.description: Various viruses can cause symptoms like fever or hypothermia, lymphadenopathy, and irritability, with specific viruses potentially leading to or exacerbating conditions like postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) and Otitis Externa.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a deficiency of red cells or of hemoglobin in the blood, resulting in pallor and weariness, which can be associated with hypothermia and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, irritability, and potentially lead to conditions similar to POTS.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing a wide variety of symptoms including those similar to POTS, lymphadenopathy, and sometimes otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in the lymphatic system. It can cause lymphadenopathy, fevers (potentially leading to hypothermia), and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, this infectious disease is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, showing symptoms like fever (or unusually hypothermia), lymphadenopathy, and irritability.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A serious infectious disease that mainly affects the lungs but can spread to lymph nodes, leading to lymphadenopathy, fever, and night sweats which may be perceived as hypothermia.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by not consuming enough fluids, which can exacerbate symptoms of POTS, lead to irritability, and in severe cases, may contribute to hypothermia.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Skin and Subcutaneous Tissue Bacterial Infections
Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections including periodontal disease, and can facilitate conditions like lymphadenitis due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes affects the body's ability to use blood sugar, potentially weakening the immune system and increasing susceptibility to various infections, including periodontal disease and more severe infections that could contribute to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Malnutrition
diagnoses.description: Malnutrition diminishes the body's ability to fight infections, potentially leading to conditions like periodontal disease, increased susceptibility to infections, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Leukemia, a type of cancer of the blood or bone marrow, can lead to a weakened immune system, making the body more susceptible to infections like periodontal disease and lymphadenitis, and can also contribute to symptoms like vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: Lupus is an autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the lymph nodes (lymphadenitis) and potentially the gums, making them more susceptible to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can lead to hypothermia due to decreased metabolism, and it may indirectly affect the immune system's efficiency, potentially contributing to an increased susceptibility to infections and related conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.description: Sepsis is a life-threatening response to an infection which can cause systemic symptoms such as hypothermia or fever, increased susceptibility to further infections, and potentially lead to lymphadenitis and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Neutropenia
diagnoses.description: This condition involves an abnormally low neutrophil count, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, which could explain the periodontal disease, lymphadenitis, and general infection susceptibility.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.description: These diseases make the body more vulnerable to infections than normal, which could explain the increased susceptibility to infections, periodontal disease, and possibly the lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Chemotherapy Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Chemotherapy can significantly weaken the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, making conditions like periodontal disease and lymphadenitis more likely, and can also cause vomiting as a side effect.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Hypertension associated with chronic kidney disease

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can explain hypermobility and potentially contribute to cyst formation. Dyslipidemia and increased appetite might be indirectly related or part of comorbid conditions.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. Symptoms might include dyslipidemia and increased appetite. While PCOS does not directly cause hypermobility or POTS, the metabolic disruptions can have wide-ranging effects on the body.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder that affects the connective tissue. The primary features are tall stature, long arms, legs and fingers, and joint hypermobility. It does not directly explain dyslipidemia or increased appetite but may contribute to cardiovascular irregularities similar to POTS.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Overproduction of thyroid hormone can lead to increased appetite, and in some cases, dyslipidemia. While it does not directly cause hypermobility or POTS, it can exacerbate symptoms like tachycardia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when the body's immune system attacks its own tissues and organs. Inflammation caused by lupus can affect many different body systems, potentially explaining a wide range of symptoms. Lupus does not directly cause cyst formation but can lead to complications affecting various organs, including the skin and kidneys, potentially leading to cysts.

diagnoses.name: Joint Hypermobility Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that features joints that easily move beyond the normal range expected for a particular joint. It is related to Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome but considered less severe. It doesn't directly cause dyslipidemia, increased appetite, or cysts but is included for joint hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol. It can lead to increased appetite, weight gain, and changes in the skin that may contribute to cyst formation. Dyslipidemia can also be a feature due to metabolic changes.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by the inappropriate release of mast cell mediators. Symptoms can include tachycardia, which may mimic POTS, and skin issues, potentially explaining cyst formation. Dyslipidemia and increased appetite are not directly explained by MCAS but could be related to overall inflammatory responses.

diagnoses.name: Familial Hypercholesterolemia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by high cholesterol levels, specifically low-density lipoprotein (LDL), leading to a risk of heart disease. While primarily associated with dyslipidemia, it does not directly explain the other symptoms but can have widespread effects on health, possibly exacerbating other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though typically associated with decreased appetite, some individuals may experience increased appetite. It can lead to metabolism dysfunctions that may indirectly contribute to dyslipidemia. It does not directly cause hypermobility, POTS, or cysts, but hormonal imbalances can have wide-ranging effects.

diagnoses: Connective Tissue Disorders (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, Rheumatoid Arthritis)

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can cause basophilia and is associated with an increased risk of infection.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells. It can also lead to an increase in white blood cells and platelets, contributing to the risk of thrombosis and atherosclerosis.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A type of chronic leukemia that affects the blood-forming tissues in the body. It can lead to fibrosis of the bone marrow, anemia, and an increased risk for infections.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: A condition generally caused by an underlying condition like hypoxia, tumors, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), leading to an overproduction of red blood cells. This can sometimes be associated with atherosclerosis due to increased blood viscosity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis or lupus can increase the risk of atherosclerosis and fibrosis, and they may potentially alter blood cell counts, impacting susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease
diagnoses.description: While not a direct cause of the other symptoms, the presence of atherosclerosis may worsen other systemic conditions and is often associated with chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the lymphatic system. It can cause increased susceptibility to infections due to immune system compromise, and it may be associated indirectly with various blood disorders.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. These can affect the body's ability to fight infection and may show symptoms like lymph node swelling.

diagnoses.name: Bone Marrow Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the bone marrow can lead to abnormal blood cell production, leading to symptoms like basophilia, polycythemia, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.description: Specific infections can cause an increase in certain blood cell types, such as basophils, and compromise the immune system, leading to an increased susceptibility to further infections. Chronic infections might also contribute to systemic inflammation and atherosclerosis.

diagnoses: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) with esophageal involvement
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Environmental allergies (such as pollen, dust mites)
Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (in the context of lupus crisis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Common Cold (as a separate reasoning for rhinorrhea)
Allergic Rhinitis (as a separate reasoning for rhinorrhea)
Adverse reactions to toxins or contaminants
Functional bowel disorders with secondary skin manifestations

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition that causes sneezing, itching, runny nose, and sometimes includes abdominal discomfort due to associated allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Vasovagal Syncope
diagnoses.description: A common cause of fainting that can be triggered by prolonged standing, emotional distress, or sudden pain, potentially including severe sneezing episodes or abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can cause a sudden drop in blood pressure (leading to syncope), along with pruritus, rhinorrhea, abdominal cramps, and more.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergies
diagnoses.description: Adverse immune responses to certain foods, which can cause symptoms such as abdominal cramps, rhinorrhea, sneezing, and occasionally syncope due to severe allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction after taking a certain medication, which can result in rhinorrhea, pruritus, abdominal cramps, and in rare cases, syncope.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition where mast cells inappropriately release chemical mediators, leading to a broad range of symptoms such as abdominal cramps, syncope, sneezing, and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Influenza (Flu)
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that affects the respiratory tract, causing symptoms including sneezing, rhinorrhea, and possibly syncope in severe cases along with general body discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A gastrointestinal disorder characterized by a group of symptoms including abdominal cramps, but can also indirectly lead to additional symptoms like rhinorrhea and possibly sneezing due to its impact on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Infection (URI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in the airways that often leads to sneezing, rhinorrhea, and could potentially worsen to the point of causing syncope through mechanisms of dehydration or fever.

diagnoses.name: Contact Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related skin condition that causes itching (pruritus), but when complicated by secondary infections or systemic reactions, can lead to rhinorrhea, sneezing, and rarely, syncope.

diagnoses: Asthma (as a part of an allergic reaction)
Contact dermatitis (if exposed to an allergen)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scotomas) before the head pain begins.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A sudden disabling attack or loss of consciousness caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain, especially through thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief, temporary interruption of blood supply to part of the brain, causing stroke-like symptoms but without lasting damage.

diagnoses.name: Neuromyelitis Optica
diagnoses.description: Also known as Devic's disease, this is a chronic disorder of the brain and spinal cord dominated by inflammation of the optic nerve (optic neuritis) and the spinal cord (myelitis).

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A growth of cells in the brain that multiplies in an abnormal, uncontrollable way. Symptoms depend on the tumor's size, location, and rate of growth.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early signs may include fever, headache, and fatigue. It can later progress to neurological problems.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological problems and pernicious anemia, causing symptoms like fatigue, weakness, numbness, and tingling.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects the nerves in the hands and feet, leading to weakness, numbness, and pain from nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the acoustic nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Pressure from the tumor can cause hearing loss, ringing in the ear, and unsteadiness.

diagnoses: Neurological effects of vitamin B12 deficiency

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, trouble speaking, understanding speech (aphasia), and dizziness or loss of balance.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). It attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers and causes communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness, weakness, balance issues, and in some cases, hearing loss.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Brainstem Aura
diagnoses.description: This is a type of migraine that can affect the part of the brain that controls functions like balance and speech. Symptoms can include vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and problems with speech (aphasia), along with numbness or tingling in one or more limbs.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can affect brain function depending on its location. Symptoms might include weakness, numbness on one side of the body, loss of hearing, difficulties with speech (aphasia), and balance issues (vertigo).

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that develops on the cranial nerve that runs from your brain to your inner ear and controls balance and hearing. It can cause hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and dizziness or loss of balance (vertigo).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) temporarily blocks blood flow to your brain. Symptoms, which usually occur suddenly, are similar to those of a stroke but don't last as long. They can include weakness, numbness, aphasia, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Circulatory Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders affect the back part of your brain that is supplied by the vertebrobasilar arterial system. Symptoms might include vertigo, difficulty speaking (aphasia), weakness, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by tick bites. Early signs may include flu-like symptoms, with later symptoms including neuropathy, hearing loss, facial palsy, and meningitis, which can lead to weakness and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Initial symptoms include weakness and tingling in the extremities. It can progress to cause paralysis, and in severe cases, it affects the muscles that control breathing.

diagnoses.name: Ménière's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear that is characterized by episodes of feeling like you're spinning (vertigo), ringing in the ear (tinnitus), hearing loss, which is sometimes temporary, and a feeling of fullness in the ear.

diagnoses: Poisoning (e.g., alcohol, lead, or other toxins)
Epilepsy with Renal Manifestations or Associated Autoimmune Disorders
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Peripheral Neuropathy due to Systemic Disease
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Lichen Planus with Hepatitis C Virus Infection
Diabetic Neuropathy with associated nephropathy and dermatologic manifestations
Guillain-Barré Syndrome with autonomic involvement and secondary skin lesions
Chronic Kidney Disease with secondary dermatologic manifestations

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with synovitis, pericarditis, proteinuria (due to lupus nephritis), photosensitive rash, and malar rash. It is often characterized by its multisystem involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While RA is classically associated with symmetrical polyarthritis, it can also feature systemic manifestations such as pericarditis and less commonly, a photosensitive rash. Synovitis is a hallmark of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features symptoms of several connective tissue diseases, including those of SLE, such as synovitis, malar rash, and possibly pericarditis and proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting exocrine glands, Sjögren's Syndrome can have systemic manifestations including arthritis (synovitis) and, rarely, renal involvement (proteinuria) and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Known for skin and muscle involvement, dermatomyositis could potentially present with a photosensitive rash and, less commonly, with pericarditis and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can involve systemic symptoms including renal (proteinuria) and cardiac (pericarditis) involvement; however, synovitis is less commonly observed.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: While less common, this vasculitis can present with skin rashes, kidney involvement (proteinuria), and muscle/joint pain (possible synovitis).

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: As primarily a kidney manifestation of SLE, lupus nephritis presents with proteinuria but can also be associated with systemic symptoms such as pericarditis and skin rashes when part of overall lupus symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Triggered by certain drugs, this condition mimics SLE and can present with symptoms such as pericarditis, proteinuria, and skin rashes, including a malar rash.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily a condition of the heart's inner lining, certain cases can mimic systemic inflammatory diseases with symptoms such as rash, renal involvement (proteinuria), and joint pain (possible synovitis). More associated with embolic phenomena but included due to the broad scope of symptoms.

diagnoses: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) with related complications
